title: jdbc driver returns no rows, just header
text:
# jdbc driver returns no rows, just header

I've been attempting to test the JDBC driver with a view to later useing it to integrate Alation Data catalog
I set up the connection with the driver
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9961593/70746579-fe8afc80-1d1d-11ea-84ad-b09a8a74860b.png)


But a query returns no rows... I can assure you that this definitely does return rows on a qpad/qstudio
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9961593/70745923-cb943900-1d1c-11ea-89e9-17f2e239f0dc.png)

i can see from the logs the query it actually runs is as follows
```
 .z.pg: ([]TABLE_TYPE:`TABLE`VIEW)^M
.z.pg: {[maxRows;fetchSize;fn;args]$[not .Q.qt r:value[fn]args;::;count r:select[maxRows]from 0!r;{neg[.z.w]@/:-1_x;last x}(0N;fetchSize)#r;r]}[0;2147483647], .o.ex, q)select from trade^M
```

is there some property i should be supplying to the driver?



## Top Comments

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: The trace is helpful. It shows that the application is setting max rows to 0, hence it is limiting the result set length to 0 rows. Somewhere the app is calling public void setMaxRows(int n) at https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/blob/master/c/jdbc.java#L137
I don't know the app, but maybe you can ask their support why they would do that?

---

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: SQL Workbench/J has a maxrows field under edit menu. It's on the status bar at the bottom of the sql editor window, and seems to default to 0. If I set it to something reasonable, it runs just fine.

---

**lozbrown**: @CharlieSkelton-Kx 
Thanks, that wasn't obvious but has made it work much better but one of my columns seems to upset this driver. 

> An error occurred when executing the SQL command:
> q)select  from trade
> 
> java.lang.ClassCastException: java.util.Date cannot be cast to java.sql.Timestamp
> 1 statement failed.
> 
> Execution time: 0.17s

Out of interest is this driver supposed to do any conversion from SQL like commands to qSQL, I've not been able to get any commands to work without using q with the q) prefix?

Probably useful to tell you what the columns are
meta trade = 
c				t	f	a
"date"			d	""	""
"sym"			s	""	"g"
"time"			t	""	""
"price"			f	""	""
"size"			i	""	""
"exchtime"		t	""	""
"seqno"			j	""	""
"salescond"		C	""	""
"conddes"		C	""	""
"taqcounter"	        i	""	""
"gmt"			z	""	""
"cleanseRef"	        h	""	""
"auditRef"		H	""	""


---

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: thanks for the details. To fix that exception, we've updated https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/blob/master/c/jdbc.jar
The jdbc driver passes the q or sql text to the server. For SQL support you should take the ps.k file from the odbc3 zip file here https://code.kx.com/v2/interfaces/q-server-for-odbc3/
and ensure that is loaded into your kdb+ process. ps.k is the sql transpiler.
Eventually, ps.k will be made available outside of odbc3.

---

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: we've also updated the driver to fix MaxRows==0 and FetchSize==0 to be interpreted as 'unlimited' - but actually 2 Billion.
thanks for pointing out these issues in our driver.

---

**lozbrown**: Thanks
This works a lot better now. Addtional the ps.k seems to work.

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9961593/71006702-abc69180-20dd-11ea-89f1-87eade7263cb.png)

metadata.author: lozbrown

I don't know the app, but maybe you can ask their support why they would do that?

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: SQL Workbench/J has a maxrows field under edit menu. It's on the status bar at the bottom of the sql editor window, and seems to default to 0. If I set it to something reasonable, it runs just fine.

title: c.obj (w32 or w64) missing
text:
# c.obj (w32 or w64) missing 

Hello,

in  order to compile under windows, I should need a c.obj, but I cannot find it.

Maybe I'm looking in the wrong place.

thanks,
Fausto


## Top Comments

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: I believe you're looking for c_static.lib
https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/blob/master/w32/c_static.lib
https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/blob/master/w64/c_static.lib

---

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: see https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/commit/badfab916ad773fd9f0bd528044c4189376f67be

---

**TheFausap**: I'm referring to that c.obj file mentioned in the comments here : 

https://github.com/KxSystems/cookbook/blob/master/c/csv.c

specifically 

```
// windows:
//  start the x86 or 64 bit version of build environment, then: cl -DKXVER=3 /MD csv.c c.obj ws2_32.lib
//  obtain c.obj from http://kx.com/q/w32/ or w64/
```
Is this an outdated information ? 

---

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: yes, that's outdated, we'll update it, thanks.
In the commit link I sent it says:"We no longer ship c.obj or cst.obj; they have been replaced by c_static.lib and cst_static.lib, and are complemented by e_static.lib and est_static.lib - these static libraries have no dependency on the aforementioned dlls."
You should probably read the rest of that too :-)

---

**TheFausap**: :) I’m sorry. Everything is ok now. 
Thank you !

top_comments:

https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/blob/master/w32/c_static.lib
https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/blob/master/w64/c_static.lib
**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: see https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/commit/badfab916ad773fd9f0bd528044c4189376f67be

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: yes, that's outdated, we'll update it, thanks.
In the commit link I sent it says:"We no longer ship c.obj or cst.obj; they have been replaced by c_static.lib and cst_static.lib, and are complemented by e_static.lib and est_static.lib - these static libraries have no dependency on the aforementioned dlls."
You should probably read the rest of that too :-)

**TheFausap**: :) I’m sorry. Everything is ok now. 
Thank you !

title: in consistent reply from q console
text: # in consistent reply from q console Hi, not sure if this is the right place for question like this I understand it's not the right syntax for the following binary atomic function, do you know why does the q produce inconsistent result? ## Top Comments **sshanks-kx**: For general discussions/questions https://forum.kx.com --- **iamjq**: Hi @sshanks-kx , thanks for the response. so you don't think this is an issue? --- **rianoc-kx**: 4 was a handle in your session. Either to another process or a file. https://code.kx.com/q/ref/hopen/#hopen Then due to some unknown external event the handle no longer became able to accept data ```q q)hopen `:file 4i q)4 +/ [1 2 3 4 5] 4 q)4 +/ [1 2 3 4 5] 4 q)4 +/ [1 2 3 4 5] ``` --- **sshanks-kx**: on linux/osx you can use lsof to view open handles/file descriptors that is in use by a running process, with their assigned number

metadata.author: iamjq
top_comments: **sshanks-kx**: For general discussions/questions https://forum.kx.com
**iamjq**: Hi @sshanks-kx , thanks for the response. so you don't think this is an issue?

**rianoc-kx**: 4 was a handle in your session. Either to another process or a file.

https://code.kx.com/q/ref/hopen/#hopen

Then due to some unknown external event the handle no longer became able to accept data

```q
q)hopen `:file
4i
q)4 +/ [1 2 3 4 5]
4
q)4 +/ [1 2 3 4 5]
4
q)4 +/ [1 2 3 4 5]
```
**sshanks-kx**: on linux/osx you can use lsof to view open handles/file descriptors that is in use by a running process, with their assigned number

title: k.h is unusable in C++ programs
text:
# k.h is unusable in C++ programs

The deliberate obfuscation of using single uppercase characters as macro names instead of meaningful identifiers makes it impossible to comingle k.h with any reasonable C++ program that uses templates in which template parameters are single letters such as T and U, which are extremely prevalent in the STL and in Boost and is generally accepted good practice for C++.

## Top Comments

**jesseconnell**: ENITETO is absolutely right.  Style is subjective, so name your variables whatever you want.  However, while everyone no doubt loves the hyper-terse, nonstandard, language-replacing syntax, preprocessor macros used to the extent seen in `k.h` are near-universally seen as bad practice and are thus avoided.  In theory, adding `#include "k.h"` could completely change behavior in completely unrelated code elsewhere.  This really, _really_ goes against good practice in C++.

---

**simon-graham**: I concur. We have to be extremely careful when using k.h from C++. The way it stomps all over the global namespace is really problematic. In practice what we normally have to do is make is make a wrapper header that #undefs O, R, Z, P, etc and everything else we don't use.

I find it highly doubtful that any end users are going to make any use of things such as `#define R return` in their own code. Perhaps we could have a cut down k.h that just includes the essentials.

---

**Yuhta**: I think we need a `k-core.h` which does not include any macro of single character to make it easier to be used in real world projects.  The old `k.h` can still include `k-core.h` to avoid code duplication.

metadata.author: EveryNameIsTakenEvenThisOne
top_comments: **jesseconnell**: ENITETO is absolutely right.  Style is subjective, so name your variables whatever you want.  However, while everyone no doubt loves the hyper-terse, nonstandard, language-replacing syntax, preprocessor macros used to the extent seen in `k.h` are near-universally seen as bad practice and are thus avoided.  In theory, adding `#include "k.h"` could completely change behavior in completely unrelated code elsewhere.  This really, _really_ goes against good practice in C++.

**simon-graham**: I concur. We have to be extremely careful when using k.h from C++. The way it stomps all over the global namespace is really problematic. In practice what we normally have to do is make is make a wrapper header that #undefs O, R, Z, P, etc and everything else we don't use.

I find it highly doubtful that any end users are going to make any use of things such as `#define R return` in their own code. Perhaps we could have a cut down k.h that just includes the essentials.

**Yuhta**: I think we need a `k-core.h` which does not include any macro of single character to make it easier to be used in real world projects.  The old `k.h` can still include `k-core.h` to avoid code duplication.

title: interfacing with C on linux problem
text:
# interfacing with C on linux problem

Hello,

I am trying to access kdb+ from within C code on a Linux (CentOS) machine, and have followed the instructions outlined in this document:

https://code.kx.com/q/wp/c_api_for_kdb.pdf 

The C code I`m using is like the one of page 4, just a simple khp/khpu to communicate with the port I set for q to listen on. (One difference is I'm using a slightly different compile command than given in that document, which is this: gcc -m32 -D KXVER=3 test.c c.o -o test -lpthread)

 I can compile my test.c code and it will run but gets stuck on the line calling the khp function. I have checked my system to see which ports are listening, and everytime I run my code it adds one byte to my RECV-Q (I take this to mean the receiving queue) on that port. It would seem as though kdb won't accept what's being communicated to it. Everything seems fine on the surface, I am getting no errors, but I am simply stuck here. 

Anyone know what might be causing this block in communication? 
Thank you 

## Top Comments

**sv**: Would you be able to provide a reproducer? C code as well as which version of kdb, how you start it and if any of handlers are redefined?

---

**sv**: You can get help quicker on our google group - https://groups.google.com/forum/?nomobile=true#!forum/personal-kdbplus

---

**Ch33m0**: Oh yes, I figured out the issue in the end! I was making a rookie mistake. Essentially I was opening up an instance of q, telling it to listen on a port, then just pressing ctrl-z to return to the bash terminal. This was keeping the q process alive, but sleeping it so it couldn't actually respond to communications. How I fixed this was to go to the folder where I run q and type : [$nohup ./q -p 5001 &] , and then press enter once. After this I was able to run my c code perfectly fine and all the outgoing q messages were handled as expected. Sorry to bother, many resources seem to omit details that can get a beginner caught up in some confusion

metadata.author: Ch33m0
top_comments: **sv**: Would you be able to provide a reproducer? C code as well as which version of kdb, how you start it and if any of handlers are redefined?
**sv**: You can get help quicker on our google group - https://groups.google.com/forum/?nomobile=true#!forum/personal-kdbplus

**Ch33m0**: Oh yes, I figured out the issue in the end! I was making a rookie mistake. Essentially I was opening up an instance of q, telling it to listen on a port, then just pressing ctrl-z to return to the bash terminal. This was keeping the q process alive, but sleeping it so it couldn't actually respond to communications. How I fixed this was to go to the folder where I run q and type : [$nohup ./q -p 5001 &] , and then press enter once. After this I was able to run my c code perfectly fine and all the outgoing q messages were handled as expected. Sorry to bother, many resources seem to omit details that can get a beginner caught up in some confusion

title: Is that away ODBC.k not only load data from MySQL but also push tables to MySQL?
text:
# Is that away ODBC.k not only load data from MySQL but also push tables to MySQL?

Just want to know if it is possible that kdb+ ODBC.k can insert data / table to MySQL? thanks

## Top Comments

**mlerner1**: bump

---

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: yes, although it is limited to submitting the command as text, for example:
```.odbc.eval[handle;"INSERT INTO mytable(textvalue, start_date, end_date) VALUES('sometextvalue','2018-01-09','2018-09-15');"]```

metadata.author: HKby
top_comments: **mlerner1**: bump

**CharlieSkelton-Kx**: yes, although it is limited to submitting the command as text, for example:
```.odbc.eval[handle;"INSERT INTO mytable(textvalue, start_date, end_date) VALUES('sometextvalue','2018-01-09','2018-09-15');"]```

Any issue with just suppressing it?

title: jdbc datetime$ ClassCastException
text:
# jdbc datetime$ ClassCastException

ResultSetMetaData reports SQL-Type 93 = java.sql.Types.TIMESTAMP for a column of type datatime$.
Therefore it should be possible to retrieve the data by ResultSet#getTimestamp at this column, but the underlying object is of type java.util.Date and can't be cast to java.sql.Timestamp and a ClassCastException is thrown instead.

title: Regarding legacy kdb binaries
text:
# Regarding legacy kdb binaries

Hey all!

I have been working on a legacy kdb codebase recently (circa 2002-2003, ~v2.9.5), I'm attempting to switch to the latest kdb+ licensed version, but I am unable to get the codebase running due to missing kdb dependencies.
Does anybody know where to download the old kdb dependencies from? (the version where the header file k20x.h exists). I would be needing the file `libk20-linux.so`, could not find this anywhere.
Using a 32bit Linux OS. Would be great if somebody could help me solve the above issue.

title: Add additional methods to JDBC driver to support Alation Data Catalog
text:
# Add additional methods to JDBC driver to support Alation Data Catalog

In order to on-board KDB databases into Alation Enterprise Data Catalog the JDBC driver must support the following methods

- getSchemas
- getTables
- getColumns
- getExportedKeys
- getPrimaryKeys
- getIndexInfo
- getTableType

These methods are part of the JDBC API spec and as such are described here:
https://docs.oracle.com/javase/7/docs/api/java/sql/DatabaseMetaData.html

For the most part these would be translations of q functions like meta and tables[]. 

[Adding a Custom Data Source – Alation.pdf](https://github.com/KxSystems/kdb/files/3979438/Adding.a.Custom.Data.Source.Alation.pdf)
